articles.headline: Bush and Relatives of Fallen Lean on Each Other
articles.snippet: In the past six years, President Bush has met hundreds of bereaved military families in deeply private sessions.
articles.abstract: In the past six years, President Bush has met hundreds of bereaved military families in deeply private sessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — Late one night last year, while her husband was an Army scout in Iraq, Melissa Storey sat in the quiet of her bedroom to write President Bush a letter. She wanted him to know “we believed in him.” And after Staff Sgt. Clint Storey, 30, was killed by a roadside bomb, his widow put pen to paper again.

articles.headline: As Oil Soars, Natural Gas Is a Bargain
articles.snippet: Oil and gas prices have never moved in lock step, in part because each has different users. But the bigger reason is that one is part of a global market and the other is not.
articles.abstract: Oil and gas prices have never moved in lock step, in part because each has different users. But the bigger reason is that one is part of a global market and the other is not.
articles.lead_paragraph: As oil prices surged over the last few months, natural gas prices in the United States did something that could help to cushion the economic shock. They fell.

articles.headline: Pakistani Leader Blocks Protests, Creating Impasse
articles.snippet: The security crackdown by Gen. Pervez Musharraf that thwarted a rally by the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto left the adversaries locked in a standoff.
articles.abstract: The security crackdown by Gen. Pervez Musharraf that thwarted a rally by the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto left the adversaries locked in a standoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 9 — The sweeping security crackdown by Gen. Pervez Musharraf that thwarted a protest rally against his emergency decree by the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto left the two adversaries locked in a standoff on Friday.
articles.byline: By David Rohde and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Analysts See Merck Victory in Vioxx Settlement
articles.snippet: While Friday’s settlement of Vioxx lawsuits at $4.85 billion seems steep, two years ago some analysts estimated that it would cost Merck as much as $25 billion.
articles.abstract: While Friday’s settlement of Vioxx lawsuits at $4.85 billion seems steep, two years ago some analysts estimated that it would cost Merck as much as $25 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the drug maker Merck to pay almost $5 billion to settle lawsuits from people who contended that the painkiller Vioxx caused their heart attacks and strokes may not seem like a corporate victory.

articles.headline: Letting a Stranger Do the Firing
articles.snippet: Some firms hire consultants to help them lay off staff; five predictors of success in a career; Nasdaq offers help to firms looking for board members and more.
articles.abstract: Some firms hire consultants to help them lay off staff; five predictors of success in a career; Nasdaq offers help to firms looking for board members and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORACLE fired people via overnight mail.

articles.headline: Another Steep Plunge Ends Harsh Week for Stocks
articles.snippet: Stocks came tantalizingly close to a flat close but plunged in the final minutes, ending a painful week on a low note.
articles.abstract: Stocks came tantalizingly close to a flat close but plunged in the final minutes, ending a painful week on a low note.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks came tantalizingly close to a flat close yesterday before plunging in the final minutes, ending a painful week in the markets on a low note.

articles.headline: House Backs Tax Relief Bill, but Fate in Senate Is Unsure
articles.snippet: The tax bill would shield millions from the alternative minimum tax next year, paid for by ending tax breaks for private-equity funds and hedge funds.
articles.abstract: The tax bill would shield millions from the alternative minimum tax next year, paid for by ending tax breaks for private-equity funds and hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — The House passed a $78.3 billion tax bill on Friday that would shield about 21 million people from the alternative minimum tax next year, and pay for it in part by ending tax breaks for private equity funds, hedge funds and other partnerships.

articles.headline: C.E.O. Evolution Phase 3
articles.snippet: After eras of empire builders and repair experts, management thinkers say the current environment demands yet another kind of C.E.O.: the team builder.
articles.abstract: After eras of empire builders and repair experts, management thinkers say the current environment demands yet another kind of C.E.O.: the team builder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has the time come for C.E.O. Version 3.0?

articles.headline: Note to N.F.L.: High Prices Cut Demand
articles.snippet: The battle between the N.F.L. and cable television providers heats up as the N.F.L. turns to the F.C.C. to try to get its way.
articles.abstract: The battle between the N.F.L. and cable television providers heats up as the N.F.L. turns to the F.C.C. to try to get its way.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Cable runs the risk of making this an issue with the regulators.” — Jerry Jones, owner

articles.headline: Countrywide’s Chief Salesman and Defender
articles.snippet: Angelo R. Mozilo considers himself and his company to be the victims of financial forces beyond their control.
articles.abstract: Angelo R. Mozilo considers himself and his company to be the victims of financial forces beyond their control.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS the credit crisis sent financial markets into a tailspin in August, Countrywide Financial, the nation’s biggest mortgage lender, was in dire need of cash. In a move that fueled anxiety among investors, it decided to tap an $11.5 billion credit line it held with a number of other banks.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: There’s No Superhero in the Wings
articles.snippet: Banks, companies, consumers. Who can rescue whom?
articles.abstract: Banks, companies, consumers. Who can rescue whom?
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST week’s ugly action in the stock market was caused in large part by fear about how badly banks will be hit by loan and securities losses. Uncertainty is ever the investor’s foe, and until we get some clarity on what banks’ holdings are truly worth, market gyrations will be a fact of life.

articles.headline: Bhutto’s Persona Raises Distrust, as Well as Hope
articles.snippet: Benazir Bhutto stands up to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, then seems to accommodate him, never revealing her intent.
articles.abstract: Benazir Bhutto stands up to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, then seems to accommodate him, never revealing her intent.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 10 — A day after she was barricaded in her home, surrounded by police officers and barbed wire, the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was quickly back to a world to which she is more accustomed on Saturday.

articles.headline: In DNA Era, New Worries About Prejudice
articles.snippet: Research is exploring how DNA explains racial differences, but it could give discredited prejudices a new potency.
articles.abstract: Research is exploring how DNA explains racial differences, but it could give discredited prejudices a new potency.
articles.lead_paragraph: When scientists first decoded the human genome in 2000, they were quick to portray it as proof of humankind’s remarkable similarity. The DNA of any two people, they emphasized, is at least 99 percent identical.

articles.headline: The Tables Turn for Dilbert’s Creator
articles.snippet: Scott Adams, the progenitor of the multimillion-dollar Dilbert empire, is now a pointy-haired boss at an upscale restaurant serving California cuisine.
articles.abstract: Scott Adams, the progenitor of the multimillion-dollar Dilbert empire, is now a pointy-haired boss at an upscale restaurant serving California cuisine.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS is yet another story about a clueless but obtrusive boss — the kind of meddlesome manager you might laugh at in the panels of “Dilbert,” the daily comic strip.

articles.headline: Broken Supply Channel Sent Arms for Iraq Astray
articles.snippet: Turmoil, bent rules and signs of theft at a Baghdad armory help explain how the U.S. lost track of some 190,000 small arms.
articles.abstract: Turmoil, bent rules and signs of theft at a Baghdad armory help explain how the U.S. lost track of some 190,000 small arms.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Eric Schmitt, Ginger Thompson, Margot Williams and James Glanz, and was written by Mr. Schmitt and Ms. Thompson.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: Screenwriters Seek Bigger Slice of Half-Eaten Pie
articles.snippet: The pot of money that the producers and writers are fighting over may have already been pocketed by the big-name talent.
articles.abstract: The pot of money that the producers and writers are fighting over may have already been pocketed by the big-name talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 — As Hollywood digs in for a second week of a strike, the screenwriters might want to send a few angry picketers over to Will Smith’s place. Or Steven Spielberg’s.

articles.headline: Musharraf Sets No Date to End Emergency Rule
articles.snippet: Gen. Pervez Musharraf said that emergency rule in Pakistan would last through elections in early January.
articles.abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf said that emergency rule in Pakistan would last through elections in early January.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 11 — Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, appeared to yield to intense American pressure on Sunday by restoring parliamentary elections in early January, but he said his emergency decree would last at least through then, immediately raising new questions about the vote’s legitimacy.
articles.byline: By David Rohde and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Cellphone Straitjacket Is Inspiring a Rebellion
articles.snippet: A rebellion is brewing in the communications industry that is expected to pit wireless carriers against Silicon Valley powerhouses like Google.
articles.abstract: A rebellion is brewing in the communications industry that is expected to pit wireless carriers against Silicon Valley powerhouses like Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: First come the grumblings, then the torches and pitchforks.

articles.headline: A Heart Stent Gets a Reprieve From Doctors
articles.snippet: Many doctors now say that the medical community overreacted to questions about drug-coated heart stents.
articles.abstract: Many doctors now say that the medical community overreacted to questions about drug-coated heart stents.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after safety questions about drug-coated heart stents prompted doctors to change treatment for hundreds of thousands of cardiac patients, many physicians say the medical community overreacted and should now reverse course.

articles.headline: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
articles.snippet: Mozilla has come to resemble a Silicon Valley start-up more than a scrappy collaborative underdog.
articles.abstract: Mozilla has come to resemble a Silicon Valley start-up more than a scrappy collaborative underdog.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a couple of years ago, Firefox was the little browser that could — an open-source program created by thousands of contributors around the world without the benefit of a giant company like Microsoft to finance it.

articles.headline: Some Wonder if the Banks’ Stabilization Fund Will Work
articles.snippet: While it may help calm the credit markets, the backup fund agreed to on Friday by the nation’s biggest banks will not save troubled structured investment vehicles that hold billions of dollars in packaged loans.
articles.abstract: While it may help calm the credit markets, the backup fund agreed to on Friday by the nation’s biggest banks will not save troubled structured investment vehicles that hold billions of dollars in packaged loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the country’s three largest banks reached agreement on Friday on how to structure a $75 billion fund to prop up distressed securities, an exhausted group of its top planners gathered in a Bank of America conference room to toast their success with 12-packs of Bud Light.

articles.headline: Living Paycheck to Paycheck Was Already a Way of Life
articles.snippet: Beyond a few superstar writer-producers who earn millions, a vast swath of working writers earn a decent but not spectacular living by making people laugh or cry.
articles.abstract: Beyond a few superstar writer-producers who earn millions, a vast swath of working writers earn a decent but not spectacular living by making people laugh or cry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bradford Winters, a screenwriter who lives and works in New York, came home very animated after walking the picket line last Monday, the first day of the Writers Guild of America’s strike against the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers.

articles.headline: Security Guard Fires From Convoy, Killing Iraqi Driver
articles.snippet: Witnesses said that a taxi driver who was shot and killed by a guard with DynCorp International, a private security company, had posed no threat.
articles.abstract: Witnesses said that a taxi driver who was shot and killed by a guard with DynCorp International, a private security company, had posed no threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Nov. 11 — An Iraqi taxi driver was shot and killed on Saturday by a guard with DynCorp International, a private security company hired to protect American diplomats here, when a DynCorp convoy rolled past a knot of traffic on an exit ramp in Baghdad, the Iraqi Interior Ministry said Sunday.

articles.headline: A New Channel for Soft Money Appears in Race
articles.snippet: Hundreds of millions of dollars are expected to pour into groups built to sway voters outside of campaign law limitations.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of millions of dollars are expected to pour into groups built to sway voters outside of campaign law limitations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The so-called Wounded Warriors Act, legislation intended to improve health care for veterans, has attracted nearly unanimous, bipartisan support in Congress. So why would the newly formed Foundation for a Secure and Prosperous America begin running a television commercial urging the citizens of South Carolina to tell Congress to pass it?
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: A Spy’s Path: Iowa to A-Bomb to Kremlin Honor
articles.snippet: George Koval, who infiltrated the Manhattan Project, was one of the most important spies of the 20th century.
articles.abstract: George Koval, who infiltrated the Manhattan Project, was one of the most important spies of the 20th century.
articles.lead_paragraph: He had all-American cover: born in Iowa, college in Manhattan, Army buddies with whom he played baseball.

articles.headline: Google Options Make Masseuse a Multimillionaire
articles.snippet: After five years of kneading Google engineers’ backs, Bonnie Brown retired and cashed in her stock options.
articles.abstract: After five years of kneading Google engineers’ backs, Bonnie Brown retired and cashed in her stock options.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 — Bonnie Brown was fresh from a nasty divorce in 1999, living with her sister and uncertain of her future. On a lark, she answered an ad for an in-house masseuse at Google, then a Silicon Valley start-up with 40 employees. She was offered the part-time job, which started out at $450 a week but included a pile of Google stock options that she figured might never be worth a penny.
